Title: Pragmatic Ischaemic Thrombectomy Evaluation (PISTE) Trial: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Background: The PISTE trial evaluated the efficacy of adjunctive intra-arterial mechanical thrombectomy (MT) in addition to intravenous thrombolysis (IVT) in patients with acute ischaemic stroke due to large artery occlusion.

Methods: This multicentre, randomised, controlled trial was conducted at 10 UK centres. Eligible patients were adults with acute ischaemic stroke, confirmed large artery occlusion on CT angiography, and IVT initiated within 4.5 hours of symptom onset. Participants were randomised 1:1 to receive IVT alone or IVT plus MT. Randomisation was performed using a minimisation algorithm, and outcome assessors were blinded. The primary outcome was independence at day 90, defined by a modified Rankin Scale (mRS) score of 0–2.

Results: Sixty-five patients were randomised between April 2013 and April 2015, with 32 receiving IVT alone and 33 receiving IVT plus MT. In the intention-to-treat analysis, no significant difference was observed in the primary outcome (adjusted OR 2.12, 95% CI 0.65 to 6.94, p=0.20). However, secondary analyses showed a greater likelihood of full neurological recovery (mRS 0–1) at day 90 with MT (OR 7.6, 95% CI 1.6 to 37.2, p=0.010). In the per-protocol population, MT significantly improved outcomes (adjusted OR 4.9, 95% CI 1.2 to 19.7, p=0.021).

Interpretation: While the primary outcome was not significantly different, MT improved secondary outcomes and was safe. Trial registration: NCT01745692. Funding: Not specified.
